Analysis.name: Incidence of herpes zoster (up to 29.4 months after final dose)
Footnotes: Herpes zoster was confirmed by skin lesion PCR, or by adjustication of the clinical case description
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Participants were randomised via central randomisation schedules by the trial statistician and the allocation sequence was concealed. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: Both participants and those delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was appropriate.
Bias.due.to.missing.outcome.data.support: Data for this outcome was available for 2678 out of 2712 participants randomised.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.
Bias.in.selection.of.the.reported.result: The data that produced this result was analysed and reported in accordance with the protocol.There was no indication for selection among multiple measurements or analyses.
Overall.bias.support: For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias for all the domains.

Analysis.name: All-cause mortality (up to 15 days post-surgery)
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: There is no information on the randomisation method and the allocation concealment. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: Both participants and those delivering the intervention were probably unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was appropriate.
Bias.due.to.missing.outcome.data.support: Data for this outcome was available for 66 out of 75 participants randomised.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: The measurement of the outcome was probybly appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were probably unaware of the intervention received.
Bias.in.selection.of.the.reported.result: According to the trial registry record, the outcome was not pre-specified as a primary or secondary outcome.
Overall.bias.support: For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias due to deviations from intended interventions, and due to measurement of the outcome. However, there are some concerns for bias from the randomization process, due to missing outcome data, and due to selection of the reported results.

Analysis.name: Incidence of COVID-19 without previous infection (up to 6 months after second dose)
Bias.arising.from.the.randomization.proc: Participants were randomised via the use of an IRT system and the allocation sequence was concealed. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.
Bias.due.to.deviations.from.intended.int: Both participants and those delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was probably appropriate.
Bias.due.to.missing.outcome.data.support: Data for this outcome was available for 1054 participants in the intervention group and 1046 participants in the control group. There is no evidence that the result was not biased by missng data, but it is unlikely that missingness depend on its true value.
Bias.in.measurement.of.the.outcome.suppo: The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.
Bias.in.selection.of.the.reported.result: We have some concerns regarding selection of the reported results because of post hoc subgroup analyses that were not pre-defined at protocol stage. There was no indication for selection among multiple measurements or analyses.
Overall.bias.support: For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias from the randomization process, due to deviations from intended interventions, due to missing outcomes and due to measurement of the outcome. However, there are some concerns for bias due to selection of the reported results.

Analysis.name: Incidence of COVID-19 (up to 16.3 months after at least one dose)
